item.title: 05 Dec 2025 01:30
item.description:
Tom’s post nudged me to revive my Digital photo frame that I set up last year. Turned it on this morning and it lit up like it was setup a minute ago. Love it! Took me a minute though to figure out how I’d initially set it up since I missed documenting it then. So here’s a quick note for posterity.

Hardware

  • Display: 15.6" Portable Display by Arzopa
  • Frame: A spare Ikea frame
  • SBC Board: A repurposed Raspberry Pi 3 from that snazzy Nextcloud Box
  • Thumb-drive for photos
  • Black Duct-tape!

Configuration

I leaned on the awesome DietPi OS for the base operating system. Once the system boots up a script runs FEH to display photos from the thumb-drive.

#! /bin/sh
cd /mnt/photos
feh -Z -z -F -D 60 --hide-pointer --auto-rotate

Essentially FEH picks up photos from the thumbdrive, random sorts them and displays a properly zoomed and oriented image every minute.

Choosing images

I currently manage my photo collection by syncing them into my Nextcloud server sorted by year, month and occasion. At the end of every month, I use Digikam to tag and export photos like-so:

  1. All photos are tagged by their month
  2. Then photos that I want to display on the screen are tagged as ‘Arzopa’.
  3. A saved search query exports these to the Thumbdrive.

Making this a manual process forces me to take a step back and actually choose what gets displayed on the screen besides giving me another opportunity to go back in time.

Next Steps

  • Setup scripts to turn off/on the screen based on the environment or time.
  • Enable touchscreen or button options to pause and navigate photos on demand. ðŸ”—

Earlier this week in Malabo, I discovered that none of my self-hosted services were working. Initially, I thought it was due to my home internet connection. However, upon returning last night, I realized that wasnâ€™t the case at all. My tiny reverse proxy, Caddy, had encountered an issue during an automated security upgrade.

Over the past few years, Iâ€™ve adopted a hands-off approach to self-hosting, setting up auto-updates for all my services. I only intervene when something breaks. Today, I decided to give my setup a little TLC, upgrading my passthrough VPS and Odroid XU4 to Bookworm. Remarkably, the process took less than 30 minutes! Thanks to Docker and Tailscale, everything connects seamlessly and just works. Love it! ðŸ”—

item.description: On my list of â€˜things to sortâ€™ is a bunch of files and physical documents that we’re compelled to move from place to place as we relocate every few years. I’ve been considering getting a document scanner to digest these files digitally and get rid of them. It’s been on my mind for a few years now and I think I’ve reached that decision threshold to bite the bullet and get a scanner. Now these devices run anywhere between 200 and 600 USD that I am NOT interested in spending for this indulgence. I’ll most likely hunt for one on ebay or backmarket sticking to my recycled hardware whenever feasible stand. The Fujitsu Fi 6130 seems to fit that ‘cheap and best’ bucket if sourced second hand. They seem to be selling for about 70 USD. ðŸ”—

item.title: 29 Nov 2024 22:41
item.description: Just struck me that most of my disk drives are quite old. Almost all of them were salvaged from old laptops. Age does not necessarily equate to performance and I do have decent backups, but only a question of time before I see them going kaput. Living vicariously on the edge when it comes to self-hosting!
